Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Programmed Intermittent Epidural Bolus Intervals for Labor Analgesia

Trial_Design.evidence: In this double-blinded, randomised controlled trial, 100 nulliparous women with singleton pregnancies at ≥37 weeks gestation were enrolled

Participants.evidence: 100 nulliparous women with singleton pregnancies at ≥37 weeks gestation were enrolled at Jiaxing University Affiliated Women and Children Hospital

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to one of five PIEB intervals (35, 40, 45, 50, or 55 minutes)

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to determine the optimal interval for programmed intermittent epidural bolus (PIEB) analgesia following dural puncture epidural (DPE) technique in laboring women.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was effective analgesia, defined as no requirement for patient-controlled epidural analgesia (PCEA) during the first stage of labor.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to one of five PIEB intervals (35, 40, 45, 50, or 55 minutes) using sequentially numbered opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for patients and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 100 nulliparous women with singleton pregnancies at ≥37 weeks gestation were enrolled

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of the 100 participants, 93 were analyzed per protocol.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Effective PIEB analgesia was achieved in 89.5% (17/19), 84.2% (16/19), 82.4% (14/17), 52.6% (11/19), and 36.8% (7/19) of patients in the 35, 40, 45, 50, and 55-minute groups, respectively. The estimated PIEB intervals for 50% (EI50) and 90% (EI90) effectiveness were 52.5 (95% CI, 48.4–62.6) and 37.0 (95% CI, 28.4–40.9) minutes, respectively.

Harms.evidence: No severe adverse events were reported.
